Question: Does the video accurately depict President Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires?

Queries.Query 1: Did President Trump visit Maui after the August 2023 wildfires?
Queries.Query 2: Fact-check Trump Maui visit August 2023 wildfires video

Query 1.title: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check
Query 1.snippet: Aug 18, 2023 ... A miscaptioned video claimed to show Donald Trump visiting Maui. In reality, it's a 2019 video of his visit to Alabama after a deadly ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... video that features former President Donald Trump and former first lady Melania Trump walking past a FEMA truck in a disaster-struck area and talking with people in a building filled with supplies and clothes.
“THE PEOPLE'S PRESIDENT,” reads text on the screen. “Thank you Mr. Trump for checking on the people of Maui!”
The Facebook video was shared over 900 times in one day, while the original TikTok video has been shared more than 7,000 times.
**Follow us on Facebook!** 
Our rating: False
-----------------
The video is years old and shows the former president's 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado damaged part of the state. Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August.
Video shows Trump visiting Alabama in 2019
------------------------------------------
At least  have died in wildfires that consumed parts of Maui, the second-largest of the Hawaiian islands, since . But there is no evidence the former president has visited the island.
The video shared on Facebook shows then-president Trump delivering remarks to a group of people at Providence Baptist Church in Opelika, Alabama, on March 8, 2019, after the area was struck by a tornado that caused serious damage and left  injured. The church was serving as a disaster relief center for those affected.
The White House shared footage of the visit on  the same day. His full comments can be found in the White House’s .
**Fact check**: 
There are no credible reports that Trump has gone to visit Maui amid the island’s wildfires. However, the former president did  about the crisis.
USA TODAY reached out to the user who shared the post for comment but did not immediately receive a response.
Our fact-check sources:
-----------------------
*   WFSA 12 News, March 3, 2022, 
*   Trump White House, March 8, 2019,  (YouTube)
*   Trump White House, March 8, 2019, 
*   Trump Campaign, Aug. 14, 
_Thank you for supporting our journalism. You can ._

It has a commitment to fact-checking and a clear editorial policy aimed at accuracy. However, its focus on brevity sometimes leads to oversimplification of complex issues, which can affect depth but not accuracy.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence explicitly debunks the claim by stating that the video in question is miscaptioned and actually shows Trump during a 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado. It directly addresses the specifics of the question, confirming that Trump did not visit Maui after the wildfires, thus establishing that the claim is false.

*   Fact Check: Did Trump visit Maui after wildfires? Viral video debunked
Fact Check: Did Trump visit Maui after wildfires? Viral video debunked
======================================================================
By 
Modified Aug 18, 2023 10:08 GMT
  Follow Us]
 ! Share
 ! 0 Discuss
  Follow Us]
 ! Share
 !(blob:https://www.sportskeeda.com/d5e6f9f9ba4ec244147bb96406df9788) 0 Discuss

What's your opinion?
Fact Check: Did Trump visit Maui after wildfires? Viral video debunked
Discuss Now
!
!
Donald Trump did not visit Maui: Social media fake news debunked. (Image via Getty Images)
 ! 
If you are active on social media, you might have come across a video claiming that former President Trump visited Maui, Hawaii, after the wildfires caused massive destruction in the area. In the 1-minute video, the former President can be seen entering a building and addressing the public, as he says:
> “These are incredible people. We met some of the survivors and family members and what they’ve been through is incredible. One woman lost 10 people in her family, an incredible woman. I said, 'How did it go?' She said, 'I lost 10, 10 people.”
!
The video was titled:
> “A real President truly cares. Trump 2024.”
In the video, Melania Trump can be seen accompanying the former president, along with a FEMA truck in the background. While the claims have been misguiding a lot of people, upon searching social media, similar videos existed that dated back to March 11, 2019, when the former President visited Beauregard, Alabama, after a tornado killed more than 15 people.
Hence, the claims that  visited the Maui wildfire are false, as the video is old and is being circulated with a fake title. On August 17, 2023, a video was shared , and within a short period of time, it received more than 2300 views.
Expand Tweet
* * *
Donald Trump did not visit Maui after wildfires
-----------------------------------------------
While the news of Trump visiting  has been circulating with an old video, the truth is that the video was taken in 2019, when Trump visited Alabama...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Sportskeeda primarily covers sports-related topics and analysis. While it may provide entertaining content, its reliability is questionable outside of sports. The focus on sports means it lacks the depth and rigor found in more traditional news sources that cover a broader range of topics, leading to a lower score for general news credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence also confirms that the video circulating is misidentified and is from a past visit. It clarifies that Trump did not visit Maui, providing strong support for the claim that the video is false.

Query 1.title: Biden says he plans to visit Maui soon as he mourns devastation ...
Query 1.snippet: Aug 16, 2023 ... President Joe Biden on Tuesday said he will travel to Maui soon to visit the devastation left behind by wildfires that ravaged the Hawaiian ...

content.content:
President Joe Biden on Tuesday said he will travel to Maui soon to visit the devastation left behind by wildfires that ravaged the Hawaiian island last week, leaving scores dead and untold damage.
    

            In his first comments on the disaster since late last week, Biden said he wanted to ensure a possible presidential visit wouldn’t impede recovery efforts.
    

            “My wife Jill and I are going to travel to Hawaii as soon as we can, that’s what I’ve been talking to governor about,” he said. “I don’t want to get in the way – I’ve been to too many disaster areas, but I want to go and make sure we got everything they need. I want to be sure we don’t disrupt the ongoing recovery efforts.”
    

            The remarks were Biden’s first public comments about the unfolding disaster in Hawaii since last Thursday, when he similarly began a prescheduled speech addressing the devastation. The period of silence had not gone unnoticed by Biden’s critics, including former President Donald Trump and other Republicans.
    

            Biden’s aides have pointed to the president’s frequent phone calls with FEMA leadership, Hawaii’s congressional delegation and its governor as evidence of his sustained engagement. So far, Democrats have publicly supported Biden’s response. The president has been in regular contact with Hawaii Gov. Josh Green, who has publicly praised the administration’s response and the president’s “full support.” Sen. Mazie Hirono of Hawaii...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CNN is a well-established news organization with a large network of reporters and correspondents. It has a reputation for breaking news and in-depth reporting, although it has faced criticism for perceived bias in its reporting. Nevertheless, CNN implements fact-checking measures and often updates its stories with accurate information. While it is not free from controversy, it has been an important outlet for credible information.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses President Biden's planned visit to Maui, which is not directly relevant to whether Trump visited Maui or not. It provides context about the situation after the wildfires but does not address Trump's actions.

“THE PEOPLE'S PRESIDENT,” reads text on the screen. “Thank you Mr. Trump for checking on the people of Maui!”
The Facebook video was shared over 900 times in one day, while the original TikTok video has been shared more than 7,000 times.
**Follow us on Facebook!** 
Our rating: False
-----------------
The video is years old and shows the former president's 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado damaged part of the state. Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August.
Video shows Trump visiting Alabama in 2019
------------------------------------------
At least  have died in wildfires that consumed parts of Maui, the second-largest of the Hawaiian islands, since . But there is no evidence the former president has visited the island.
The video shared on Facebook shows then-president Trump delivering remarks to a group of people at Providence Baptist Church in Opelika, Alabama, on March 8, 2019, after the area was struck by a tornado that caused serious damage and left  injured. The church was serving as a disaster relief center for those affected.
The White House shared footage of the visit on  the same day. His full comments can be found in the White House’s .
**Fact check**: 
There are no credible reports that Trump has gone to visit Maui amid the island’s wildfires. However, the former president did  about the crisis.
USA TODAY reached out to the user who shared the post for comment but did not immediately receive a response.

On the other hand, the former President did speak up on the matter and acknowledged the situation, as he took a dig at the current President, , and said:

A shortened video distorts Hawaii governor’s comments about the state buying land in Lahaina
============================================================================================
Gov. Josh Green said he was looking for ways for the state to buy land in Lahaina to preserve it for local residents.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
!
Hawaii Gov. Josh Green, left, and Maui County Mayor Richard Bissen, Jr., speak during a tour of wildfire damage on Saturday, Aug. 12, 2023, in Lahaina, Hawaii. (AP Photo/Rick Bowmer)
By: 
August 18, 2023
(javascript:;)
Some Maui residents displaced by wildfires said that  are approaching them to , leading to concerns among locals .
Hawaii Gov. Josh Green addressed those concerns in a recent interview, suggesting that the state could buy some land in the historic city of Lahaina to preserve it and protect it from outside developers.
Now, some social media users are presenting a shortened clip of his comments to falsely claim his comments show a state plan to usher in smart cities.
Sticker text on an  read, “Governor (Josh) Green wants to turn Lahaina Maui into state lands. All planned for smart city.
The video played an Aug. 12 clip from local TV news station KHON showing Green talking to reporters in Lahaina.
“I’m already thinking about ways for the state to acquire that land, so that we can put it into workforce housing,” he said in the clip. The Instagram video then cut to a man speaking in a  video.
“Let me get this straight,” he said. “The houses burned down. Most of the trees are fine. The governor’s talking about how to acquire the land and...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: Similar to evidence2, this evidence focuses on comments made by Hawaii’s governor and is unrelated to the claim about Trump. It provides no support or refutation of the claim itself.

QA.Question: Does the video accurately depict President Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires?
QA.Answer: The video does not accurately depict President Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires. The information provided indicates that the video actually shows a past event in March 2019, during Trump's visit to Alabama after a tornado struck that area. The video was miscaptioned and falsely claimed to depict his visit to Maui after the recent wildfires. Multiple fact-checks confirm that Trump has not visited Maui following the wildfires, and the footage circulating online is an outdated clip from his 2019 trip [Query 1_evidence_1][Query 2_evidence_2]. Given the strong evidence from reputable sources confirming the misleading nature of the video and the misrepresentation of the event, I am confident in my conclusion.
